text: [Music]
hi
welcome back to the break room i am
jason kessler i used to work on the
office for the first four
seasons and you can learn a little more
about me if you watch the video right
um here so the whole point of the break
room is to talk about
questions that you the super fan have
about the show and what it was like to
work
behind the scenes um so let's start with
a question that i get asked all the time
which is what is it like to write an
episode
of the office how does that happen
what's the process
does every writer write for a specific
character the answer to that last one is
no
every writer does not write for a
specific character although that's murky
a little bit on the office because you
have somebody like bj novak or mindy
kaling
or paul lieberstein who play characters
on the show
so they know the voice of that character
better than anybody
so they kind of write for their
characters more than the other writers
but um the general process i've come up
with
a pretty good metaphor for it and it's
kind of like an
hourglass right so you have the bottom
of the hourglass and that's like the
beginning of the season all of the
writers are in a room together and if
you want to close your eyes and picture
the office writer's room
it's a big open room with a giant long
table on it
and note cards everywhere and the note
cards have
two words three words that represent a
story that somebody's pitched
there's also an area with couches like
right over here
that have uh we had rock band we played
a lot of rock band during breaks
we would eat lunch at the big long
writer's table
um fun place to be if you want to be
stuck in a room for 14 to 17 hours
a day back to the hourglass the
hourglass
starts with all of the writers in the
room pitching wouldn't it be funny if
this happened what if we did a story on
on this
and stories morph over time my
job in the very beginning was as the
writer's assistant so i would sit behind
a computer
and i would furiously try to take notes
as some of the funniest writers in the
world
throughout funny jokes and ideas what's
really cool is from the very inception
of a story something like
what if it was funny if if michael
appeared on a kid's tv show back when he
was a kid
and you see how that takes shape now if
you're a
big time office fan you know what i'm
referring to became
fundal bundle but uh and that was on the
take your daughter to work episode
but what you might not know is that that
started being called hatchimalachi
which i'm i'm almost 100 sure was from
mindy kaling i'm looking at the notes
right now that i actually took about it
and it's incredible because we have
notes like this is a good combo because
incorporates
the themes of people that have dreams
but don't necessarily get the chance to
live them out
michael makes a reference to land of the
lost which is interesting
and he's michael has a talking head
about his child stardom which says
why couldn't i be more like kirsten
dunst or drew barrymore
so we have pages and pages of jokes like
truly this this is nine pages on a word
document from
one day of pitching so anyway we're back
the hourglass or the bottom of the
hourglass you talk about the story
you talk about the story and this
happens over days weeks
months sometimes finally when you know
what the shape of the story is
you get to the middle of that hourglass
and one writer
is assigned to go off and write that
episode and that's the name you see on
tv where it says written by
let's say michael sher um that's because
he wrote the first draft of that episode
and when they bring that episode back
you open the hourglass up again
and every writer pitches in and helps to
rewrite the episode
so the writing process is everybody all
at once
joke joke joke story story story what
could happen here what could happen here
middle of that hourglass one writer
takes all of the notes pages and pages
and pages
and creates the actual first draft of
the episode
and then it comes back in you open the
hourglass back up
and all of a sudden everybody's
rewriting together
now that i'm talking about this i feel
like i have the hourglass upside down so
let's
do that yes start here
go here finish here that's your whole
episode
um i hope that answers your question
i'm here to answer so many more
questions
so if you have any other questions about
the office about what it was like behind
the scenes what it was like to work on
the show
um please please submit them in the
comment section
right here i'm getting used to pointing
to things and we'll answer them on the
next installment of the break room
and thanks for being fans of the office
on peacock um it's so nice to be able to
talk about the show again
oh
